submitdata.deceasedDomicile: live (domicile) permanently in England or Wales

legalStatement.intro: This statement is based on the information Applicant NAme has given in their application. It will be stored as a public record.
legalStatement.deceased: deceased person was born on 1 February 1900 and died on 1 February 2000, domiciled in England and Wales.
legalStatement.applicant:
We, Applicant NAme of my address
 and exec_3_new_name of exec3_address
, make the following statement:
legalStatement.deceasedEstateLand: To the best of our knowledge, information and belief, there was no land vested in deceased person which was settled previously to the death (and not by the will) of deceased person and which remained settled land notwithstanding such death.
legalStatement.deceasedOtherNames: They were also known as name another,alias an and someoneelse aka.
legalStatement.deceasedEstateValue: The gross value for the estate amounts to £222222 and the net value for the estate amounts to £22222.

declaration.accept: I confirm that I will administer the estate of the person who died according to law, and that my application is truthful.
declaration.confirm: We confirm that we will administer the estate of deceased person, according to law. We will:
declaration.requests: If the probate registry (court) asks us to do so, we will:
declaration.confirmItem2: keep full details (an inventory) of the estate
declaration.confirmItem3: keep a full account of how the estate has been distributed
declaration.requestsItem1: provide the full details of the estate and how it has been distributed
declaration.requestsItem2: return the grant of probate to the court
declaration.understandItem1: our application will be rejected if we do not provide information (if asked)
declaration.understandItem2: criminal proceedings for fraud may be brought against us if we are found to have been deliberately untruthful or dishonest

executorsNotApplying.notApplyingReason: This executor died (before the person who has died)
This executor died (after the person who has died)
This executor doesn’t want to apply now, but may do in the future (this is also known as power reserved)
This executor doesn’t want to apply now, and gives up the right to do so in the future (this is also known as renunciation, and the executor will need to fill in a form)
